1.5 Emergency Response Program (ERP)

Gill's Onions has developed written emergency procedures to address elements that may be encountered during planning, responding or follow-up to an emergency at the facility. Application of the emergency procedures ensures compliance with OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.38 (Emergency Action Plans) within the emergency response element of the Risk Management Plan. The basic concept of Gill's Onions emergency procedures is to provide a comprehensive approach for managing emergencies. The four elements of this approach are prevention, preparedness, response, and recovery.

The Plant does participate in emergency response activities under the HAZWOPER standard in a defensive manner only.  Plant employees are to implement hazard communications, provide for the safety of visitors and report to the established Evacuation Staging Area(s) for a head count.  Emergency response is coordinated with the City of Oxnard Fire/CUPA.  The Refrigeration personnel and/or other Management would be available to support the Fire Department as technical resources.  The facility has communicated with Oxnard Fire/CUPA to be included in the Oxnard Community Emergency Plan.     

The ERP is designed to be applicable to any type of emergency that may affect Gill's Onions and based on the concept that the elements of emergency response are similar, regardless of the hazard. T

1.4 Summary of the Five-Year Accident History 

On 9/16/2022 Gill's Onions had an accidental release of ammonia. The accident occurred at approximately 9pm. The accident occurred when a solenoid coil had grounded to plunger tube and burned hole on post causing liquid ammonia to leak. The release was determined to be caused by the malfunctioning solenoid valve. The duration of the release was estimated to be 6 hours 18 minutes. The amount of ammonia released was estimated to be approximately 1,095.2 lb. The local CUPA, 911, CalEMA, and the National Response Center were notified. 

An investigation was performed and the following recommendations were made and are being resolved:

Recommendation 1: During the emergency response, there was confusion as to which agencies were required to be notified and what order the notifications should be made. Train appropriate personnel responsible for making the release notifications on the appropriate agencies to be notified in the event of an ammonia release, order of notifications, and timeline to make such notifications.

1.1 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Gill's Onions policy is to protect its employees, environment, property, and the general public from harm that may occur as a result of its operations. To achieve this end, Gill's Onions strives to operate its facilities in compliance with applicable federal, state, and local safety, health, and environmental regulations.  With regard to the Ammonia Refrigeration and SCR Systems, the Accidental Release Prevention policy is to maintain compliance with the Risk and Process Safety Management Prevention Program elements.  The RMP/PSM programs are specifically designed and intended to prevent accidental releases; and to deal safely with emergencies if they do happen.

Gills Onions has adopted a Non-responding facility policy; Emergency Response pre-planning is coordinated with the Oxnard Fire/CUPA; and Facility Management.  Gills Onions has filed appropriate reports with the CUPA; measures have been taken to ensure the facility is included in the Community Emergency Plan.  The CUPA makes regular visits to the facility in accordance with California environmental regulations, which helps keep engine companies refreshed on Plant operations and layout.  The Gills Onions Emergency response policies are implemented to comply with the overall company policy of providing its workers with a safe workplace and minimizing risk to the public. Safety is the top priority.  Another priority is protection of the environment. Only after life, safety, environmental concerns are addressed will the focus shift to the secondary issues of property conservation and business recovery.

1 EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Pursuant to the requirements of Title 40 Code of Federal Regulations Part 68.1 through 68.220 and Chapter 6.95, Article 2 of the California Health & Safety Code A§25531 through A§25543.3, this Risk Management Plan (RMP) is implemented as the California Accidental Release Prevention (Cal/ARP) Risk Management Plan under the Program Level 3 Designation.

The scope of this RMP is based on guidance from the City of Oxnard Fire Department Certified Unified Program Agency (Oxnard Fire/CUPA- the Agency with local authority for the RMP and Cal/ARP Programs), to ensure that contemporary issues are resolved and to incorporate state requirements.  The facility uses anhydrous ammonia (CAS 7664-41-7) in a closed-loop refrigeration process (18,000 lbs. maximum intended inventory) for temperature control of fresh onions.  Under a separate process, anhydrous ammonia is used in a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system (300 lbs. maximum).  The SCR is used to control nitrogen oxides (NOX) emissions from a one Mega Watt natural gas-fired turbine. The ammonia refrigeration system and SCR processes trigger the RMP requirements, both Federal and Cal/ARP. These processes were determined to be covered by Prevention Program III requirements.

At the time of this writing, the SCR Process was not being used; and the ammonia inventory in the SCR Receiver was negligible.  The facility however considers power backup essential to its business operations; this second Process will be kept on standby.
